title: 110_s2299
content: The Act titled "National Aquatic Animal Health Act of 2007" provides oversight for the National Aquatic Animal Health Plan. The National Aquatic Animal Health Act of 2007 defines key terms like advisory committee, plan, and Secretary. The General Advisory Committee for Oversight of National Aquatic Animal Health is established to oversee the national aquatic animal health plan. The General Advisory Committee for Oversight of National Aquatic Animal Health is established by the Secretary within 180 days of the Act's enactment. It will consist of representatives from State and tribal governments, as well as commercial aquaculture interests, with a maximum of 20 members appointed by the Secretary. The General Advisory Committee for Oversight of National Aquatic Animal Health will have a maximum of 20 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from Federal departments, State or tribal governments, affected commercial aquaculture interests, and aquatic animal health experts. Nominations will be published by the Secretary. The Secretary will publish a solicitation for nominations for members of the advisory committee from appropriate entities. The advisory committee will develop recommendations on expert commissions, best management practices, and plan administration within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The advisory committee will consider emergency aquaculture projects under the plan. States, tribal governments, and private entities can choose to participate in the plan by submitting required information to the Secretary. The advisory committee will consider emergency aquaculture projects under the plan. States, tribal governments, and private entities can participate by submitting required information to the Secretary and entering into an agreement to share costs and follow best practices. The non-federal share of the cost for carrying out the plan will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with the advisory committee on a case-by-case basis. State, tribal governments, and entities in the private sector can provide the share in cash or in-kind. The Secretary, in consultation with the advisory committee, will establish an indemnification fund with initial deposits from the Secretary. The non-Federal share for the fund will be determined on a case-by-case basis for each project, provided by State, tribal governments, or private entities in cash or in-kind. The Secretary will establish an indemnification fund with deposits from various sources for compensating aquatic farmers for losses due to disease control measures or depopulation orders. Unused amounts in the fund will carry over to the next fiscal year. The Secretary will establish an indemnification fund for compensating aquatic farmers for losses. The fund will remain in place, can be used in subsequent years, and cannot be reallocated for other purposes. A review will be conducted after 2 years to assess activities and make funding recommendations for future years. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $15,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2008 and 2009. Not less than 50% for indemnification fund, not more than 50% for plan costs including administration, implementation, training, cleaning, public education.
